qas.question: What has not been reached as far as defining comics is concerned?
R. C. Harvey, Will Eisner and others are considered to be comic what?
What are there prominent examples of in comic history?
Comic critics, such as McCloud, stressed that sequences of what should be primary?
What century had forgotten comic forms rediscovered?
What has been reached as far as defining comics is concerned?
R. C. Harvey, Will Eisner and others are not considered to be comic what?
What aren't there prominent examples of in comic history?
Comic critics, such as McCloud, stressed that sequences of what should be secondary?
What century had remembered comic forms rediscovered?

context: Similar to the problems of defining literature and film, no <a0_0><b5_0>consensus<b5_0/><a0_0/> has been reached on a definition of the comics medium, and attempted definitions and descriptions have fallen prey to numerous exceptions. <a1_0><b6_0>Theorists<b6_0/><a1_0/> such as Töpffer, R. C. Harvey, Will Eisner, David Carrier, Alain Rey, and Lawrence Grove emphasize the combination of text and <a3_0>images<a3_0/>, though there are prominent examples of <a2_0><b7_0>pantomime comics<b7_0/><a2_0/> throughout its history. Other critics, such as Thierry Groensteen and Scott McCloud, have emphasized the primacy of sequences of <b8_0>images<b8_0/>. Towards the close of the <a4_0><b9_0>20th<b9_0/><a4_0/> century, different cultures' discoveries of each other's comics traditions, the rediscovery of forgotten early comics forms, and the rise of new forms made defining comics a more complicated task.
